Summary: The proposal aims to develop a scalable infrastructure for distributed deep learning (DDL) that optimizes communication and computation in heterogeneous clusters. It identifies inefficiencies in current frameworks and proposes a three-part solution: adaptive communication, hardware-aware scheduling, and lightweight profiling. The experiment plan includes benchmarking, validation of adaptive strategies, and ablation studies.
Strengths: Strong motivation with a compelling hypothesis.
Comprehensive proposed method combining adaptive communication, scheduling, and profiling.
Detailed and rigorous experiment plan, including ablation studies and scalability tests.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion of technical challenges (e.g., overhead of real-time profiling).
Ambitious claims (e.g., 30% reduction in training time) without preliminary results or theoretical analysis.
Limited discussion on handling extreme heterogeneity or failover scenarios.
Questions: What is the expected overhead of the real-time profiling mechanism?
How will the system handle extreme heterogeneity (e.g., nodes with vastly different capabilities)?
Can you provide any preliminary results or theoretical analysis to support the 30% reduction claim?
Limitations: Potential overhead from real-time profiling and dynamic adaptation.
Complexity of integrating reinforcement learning for straggler prediction.
Scalability under extreme heterogeneity or network failures.
